replies.bodyText:
Jamie's feedback - The one UX comment I had was around the duration of the loading screen - is there a scenario where loading could be very quick and this screen is flashed to the viewer too quickly? Is there a mechanism to address that?
So added a 5 seconds delay for form submission.
replies.author: dhanyak-btc

replies.bodyText: I can discuss with Jamie, but this doesn't really make sense. There's nothing to show the user here, why does it matter how fast it is? Or just don't make it auto login
replies.author: nikklassen

replies.bodyText: agree with Nik. I think a better solution is to skip this screen if we find that it's flashing too quickly. Adding manual delay doesn't sound like a good user experience to me.
replies.author: zohrehj

replies.bodyText: @jkrogers18 adding you for visibility
replies.author: zohrehj

replies.bodyText: 5 second delay was the designer's suggestion. What I'm concerned about is a quick flash of a screen that confuses a user and looks unprofessional. I've seen this in other parts of the mobile app so wanted to make sure we weren't getting into another situation like that here. We should pursue the better solution if there is one. I imagine there are standard design patterns around this kind of thing.
replies.author: jkrogers18

replies.bodyText: I'm not clear on the flow here, instead of sending the user to this page then submitting the form why can't we submit the form from the original screen? I think having the user manually proceed would be better than a 5 second delay, I can submit a form myself faster than that.
replies.author: nikklassen

replies.bodyText:
During Hydra POC, I tried my best to skip the consent flow and get the authorization code from Hydra but unfortunately it didn't work so we discussed and decided to add a "Please wait.." screen with auto submit.
During POC I also added a "Accept" button on consent page but got feedback to make it auto submit with "Please wait..." message for better UX.
For sign in after signup flow, there are nearly 10 API calls are made so IMO it's not a good UX if we open a WebView/Chrome Tabs (mobile) and display empty screen until all the API calls are completed.
1- GET /oauth2/auth 
2- GET /login (oauth scim controller)
3- POST /login (from oauth scim view)
4- PUT /oauth2/auth/requests/login/accept
5- GET /consent (oauth scim controller)
6- GET /oauth2/auth/requests/consent
7- POST /consent (from oauth scim view)
8- PUT /oauth2/auth/requests/consent/accept
9- GET /login (with 'code' in query params)
10. Redirect to callback URL with authorization code
replies.author: dhanyak-btc

replies.bodyText:
I am okay with the flow as is, and showing the wait screen. Only objection is unnecessary wait for users. We should only wait until all the requests have been made.
It is also possible to display a modal with please wait message in the original screen, while all the calls are being done in the background.
replies.author: zohrehj

replies.bodyText: If we can do this as a modal on the same page that may make this a non-issue. If a rotating circle of dots shows up to indicate loading that would be good. If loading takes several seconds the user will understand, but if the loading is very fast then flashing those gray dots isn't as confusing as flashing a whole new screen.
replies.author: jkrogers18

replies.bodyText: At the very least I would reduce this to <= 2 seconds. That's plenty of time for the user to register what this page is
replies.author: nikklassen

replies.bodyText: Reduced the wait time to 2 seconds.
replies.author: dhanyak-btc

timeline.bodyText: nit: no need to enforce size in regex since you already have min and max specified.
timeline.author: zohrehj

replies.bodyText:
It doesn't look like we are requiring spacial characters in the password here, which I thought was a requirement.
Also not sure why we are limiting the spacial characters that the user can use?
why not just accept whatever they provide, and just enforce the min character?
replies.author: zohrehj

replies.bodyText:
I copied this regex from old auth server to keep the password requirement AS-IS. This regex is used in create account, change password and authentication, kindly a create an issue if the password requirements has changed so that I can fix it in all 3 places together.
I noticed so many slash () added by STS when the regex is copy-pasted, fixed this.
replies.author: dhanyak-btc

replies.bodyText:
requirement has not changed, my feedback is to simplify the regex:

combine the first three groups with [A-Za-z0-9] instead of specifying them separately
instead of listing spacial characters one by one, use a simpler logic, e.g, [^A-Za-z0-9] which is the negation of the alphanumeric characters.
